data.title: BitmapFontCache.draw crashes if empty
data.body:
The draw() method of BitmapFontCache crashes, if the cache is clear (i.e. after a call to clear).

The following pastebin shows the problem:
http://pastebin.com/2Z0BKN3f

Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" java.lang.NullPointerException
        at java.lang.System.arraycopy(Native Method)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch.draw(SpriteBatch.java:631)
        at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.BitmapFontCache.draw(BitmapFontCache.java:205)

draw() should include if the cache is empty, and if so should not relate the draw call to the batch.

data.title: add glyphs after fully creating BitmapFont
data.body:
This will be especially useful for drawing many Asian characters. because there are so many of them, you can load them individually when the user needs to. 

 For example, if there are glyphs for 'H', 'e', 'l' loaded in the BitmapFont, and I want to print "Hello". Obviously the font doesn't have an 'o', so it will only print "Hell". What I want to do is load 'o' into the font at the time draw() method is called from a freetype font file or anything like that.

But why don't I load all the glyphs at once? Because there are too many. If I load all 40000+ glyphs that I need at once, it takes about 30 secs to load them all. There are glyphs that doesn't even get used once from the beginning to the end.

I tried some things to make it work, but there are some internal variables inside the BitmapFont that I can't get access to. So I found that it is almost impossible without changing the source code.

So what I request is you devs should enable BitmapFont to add more glyphs when it is finished initializing. If you do, it would be a huge leap for multi-language support. (I'm new to Github I just joined five minutes ago, and sorry about the bad English, English is not my mother language as you have guessed from the subject of this, I'm sorry if this place is not the place to post requests, please erase this if it isn't.)

A simple picture I drew in MSPaint to demonstrate what I want to do:

![hello](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/6328181/1849379/71c5a8d6-76b1-11e3-9e08-daf0b9372de6.png)

data.body:

So I've created this issue as a base for them.

Is it going to be implemented in future?

data.title: added boolean isOpenedBelow() to SelectBox
data.body: returns the boolean wether the selectbox-list is opened above or below the selectbox.

data.title: Opengl es 3.0 support
data.body:
This contains an interface for es 3.0 functions and constants. I've implemented this interface in the lwjgl backend only.

I've also added some tests showing the more readily visible features of es 3.0, under gdx-tests/src/com/badlogic/gdx/tests/gles3

Everything is commented, but for the tests, some background in the techniques demonstrated is recommended.

data.title: removing vertices on a polygon won't make the transformed vertices array smaller
data.body:
the worldVertices in Polygon is never shrinked, it's only made bigger if we add vertices to the local vertices. But if we remove some, it is not shrinked. Thus it will result in many problems, such as buggy display if we render the polygon with ShapeRenderer#polygon

Is this behavior intended? If yes, how do I work around this? Create a new Polygon each time I'm removing vertices from it?

If it's not intended, the fix would be just a one line change, I can easily make a pull request

data.title: Upload gdx-controllers to maven central
data.body: Could you upload the gdx-controllers extension to maven central? Would be very useful for the Gradle template. Or is there any special reason this shouldn't/hasn't be done?

data.title: Missing getAlpha() in Sprite
data.body:
There is no getAlpha() method in the Sprite class which is very annoying.
Please add it. :+1:

data.title: (0.9.9) wrong texture used in SpriteBatch after using a shader
data.body:
Context:
Rendering something using a custom shader with multiple textures (e.g. calling Gdx.gl.glActiveTexture(GL20.GL_TEXTURE2);), then rendering something using SpriteBatch (e.g. drawing a BitmapFont, Image, etc.).

Problem:
LibGdx uses the wrong texture in the SpriteBatch. It still uses one of the textures from the custom shader.

Solution:
The problem is that the active texture is GL20.GL_TEXTURE2 instead of GL20.GL_TEXTURE0. So before using the SpriteBatch, we need to call Gdx.gl.glActiveTexture(GL20.GL_TEXTURE0);, then everything is fine.

Remark:
I don't now if this is a bug or not, but it took me a long time to find the solution to this problem.

data.title: Fix for pause() not being called on iOS backend
data.body:
Application pause() was not being called sometimes when there was no draw() call after the IOSGraphics pause() was called.

Moved most of the pause handling out of the draw method.

Described here: http://www.badlogicgames.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=11&t=11481

data.title: Removed unneeded wakelock permissions from demos
data.body: The new wakelock method doesn't require this permission. :)

data.title: scene2d Dialogs with wrapped text
Broken Culling
data.body:
I have been working a little more with libGDX again and tried TiledMaps. Everything was fine, but when the camera rotates parts of the rendered map are cut off. Not sure if this is a mistake in my setup or a bug.

The map should usually look squared, but when the camera is rotated and moved parts are cut off.

![broken](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/907766/1827675/91c2f0c2-723c-11e3-85e3-8ad3553dd1e5.png)
![good](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/907766/1827676/91c4693e-723c-11e3-8558-39accfbe1912.png)

data.title: getRawDeltaTime() should return 0 when setContinuousRendering() changed from false to true
AssetManager in GWT: Error on loading never calls the error handler
data.body:
When you run the TiledMapAtlasAssetManagerTest from PR #1131 with GWT an error message should be shown indicating that the map could not be loaded.
Instead the screen just stays blank which means the error handler from the AssetManager has never been called.

On the desktop the error handler is called (if for example the map's filename is changed to a non existing file).

This also results in an endless loop in GWT if AssetManager#finishLoading is used.

I tried to debug into the generated JavaScript but could not find the reason why the AssetManager never stops loading in this case.

data.title: Removed GWT emu for AtlasTmxMapLoader and TmxMapLoader
data.body:
This removes duplicated code for the GWT emulations and is a preparation for issue #1087
AtlasTmxMapLoader and TmxMapLoader now use the emulated GZIPInputStream and InflaterInputStream classes (which throw exceptions on read).

data.title: Removed unneeded method parameters and OverlapTester object
data.body: Removed unneeded method parameter usages of deltaTime. Removed OverlapTester class because it's all wrapped up in the Rectangle class and isn't obvious to new users.

data.title: Removed unneeded method parameters and OverlapTester object
data.body:
Removed OverlapTester class because it's all wrapped up in the Rectangle class and isn't obvious to new users.  The exact same code is used in Rectangle.contains and Rectangle.overlap.

I've also removed the dead parameters where the deltaTime is being passed around but it's never used other than a few sparse places.

data.title: JNI error using ART runtime instead of Dalvik
data.body:
When using a simple-ish GDX app on the new experimental ART VM on Android, I get a crash in calling `NewDirectByteBuffer` with a size of 0. I believe it is specified that you should not do this in the JNI docs, however, Dalvik allows this. ART is more strict and does not. Unfortunately, many JNI apps rely on this behaviour.

To gain compatibility with ART, we must make sure no calls to `NewDirectByteBuffer` are made with size 0. This will not break Dalvik compatibility.

The error originates (fairly predictably) from `com.badlogic.gdx.utils.BufferUtils`

data.title: Couldn't load shared library 'libgdx64.so' for target: Linux, 64-bit
data.body:
Exception in thread "main" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Couldn't load shared library 'libgdx64.so' for target: Linux, 64-bit
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SharedLibraryLoader.load(SharedLibraryLoader.java:110)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxNativesLoader.load(GdxNativesLoader.java:34)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglNativesLoader.load(LwjglNativesLoader.java:46)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication.<init>(LwjglApplication.java:76)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication.<init>(LwjglApplication.java:64)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication.<init>(LwjglApplication.java:56)
    at com.badlogicgames.superjumper.SuperJumperDesktop.main(SuperJumperDesktop.java:23)
Caused by: com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Unable to read file for extraction: libgdx64.so
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SharedLibraryLoader.readFile(SharedLibraryLoader.java:119)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SharedLibraryLoader.loadFile(SharedLibraryLoader.java:231)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SharedLibraryLoader.load(SharedLibraryLoader.java:108)
    ... 6 more

How to solve?
